docs.lead_paragraph: The feeding room here is quiet. The children are so severely malnourished that they barely move anymore. There is no laughing, no teasing, no giggling, no squirming -- none of the things that should come naturally when 40 children are crowded together for a meal. In fact, even eating does not really appeal to them. In many cases, their mouths must be forced open and the milk slowly poured down their throats. Here in this city under siege -- an island of Government-controlled land surrounded by rebels -- starvation is beginning to set in. In little more than six months, rebel forces have taken back about 70 percent of this country, so rich in oil and diamonds, flushing more than a million Angolans off the land and into the cities, where aid organizations try to dole out food to the most needy.

headline.main: Hunger Ravages Angolans in Renewed Civil War

docs.abstract: Starvation takes hold in Huambo, Angola, little more than six months after rebel forces regained control over almost 70 percent of country; fighting has forced more than million Angolans off land and into cities, where aid organizations press efforts to dole out food to most needy; workers say appeals for more food are being ignored, even as shelling of local airport often forces planes full of grain to turn away; say indifference to life is new phenomenon prevalent among population, with many refugees having little desire to survive anymore; are demanding that malnourished children eat at distribution stations because parents are so desperate that they steal from own children; situation in and around city described; renewed fighting is crude struggle over money and power; both sides are well financed, with Govt controlling oil territories and Unita rebel organization diamonds, reportedly with portfolio of carefully invested stocks and bonds worth $4 billion; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The feeding room here is quiet. The children are so severely malnourished that they barely move anymore. There is no laughing, no teasing, no giggling, no squirming -- none of the things that should come naturally when 40 children are crowded...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL UNION FOR TOTAL INDEPENDENCE OF ANGOLA

docs.lead_paragraph: The female condom, seldom used in the West, is catching on here and in many parts of the developing world, slowly becoming an important new weapon in the fight against the AIDS epidemic. Nearly seven million have been distributed in 34 countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America, and the device is gaining acceptance among men as well as women.

headline.main: Condoms for Women Gain Approval Among Africans

docs.abstract: Female condom, seldom used in West, is catching on in South Africa, finding favor with men as well as women, and it is slowly becoming an important new weapon in fight against AIDS epidemic; United Nations AIDS and other organizations working to persuade more women to try the female condom are first approaching prostitutes and other women with multiple partners, since persuading them to use condoms has notably reduced rates of AIDS infection; female condom, properly used, is believed to be as good as or better than the male condom at preventing infection and is slightly less effective than male condom at preventing pregnancy; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The female condom, seldom used in the West, is catching on here and in many parts of the developing world, slowly becoming an important new weapon in the fight against the AIDS epidemic.     Nearly seven million have been distributed in 34 countries...

docs.lead_paragraph: After a day of frantic arm-twisting and deal-making, Republican leaders in the House took a big step toward salvaging their cherished tax-cutting bill early today, winning a critical procedural vote rewriting the legislation to quell a revolt by party moderates. Prospects for passage of the $792 billion tax cut improved substantially after Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and other senior Republicans pressured, cajoled and finally made a deal with about a dozen moderates who said the tax cut was too big and left too little money for debt reduction and domestic spending.

headline.main: Concessions by G.O.P. Leaders Breathe Life Into Tax-Cut Plan

docs.abstract: House Republican Leaders, scrambling to salvage $792 billion tax cut, win key procedural vote on rules governing debate, 219-208, after rewriting bill to quell revolt by party moderates; agree to tie phased 10 percent cut in personal income tax rates to success in reducing national debt; Senate Finance Committee approves $778 billion tax cut package with features different from House bill; Pres Clinton again threatens to veto either version, news conference; pledges to work with both parties for smaller tax cut; photo (M)
docs.snippet: After a day of frantic arm-twisting and deal-making, Republican leaders in the House took a big step toward salvaging their cherished tax-cutting bill early today, winning a critical procedural vote rewriting the legislation to quell a revolt by...
